org.heavymeta.vehicles
Interface Renderer

public interface Renderer

An object that implements the Renderer interface can be used to render a World at an instantaneous moment of the World's time. The Renderer interface is intended to be flexible enough to encompass simple 2D graphics, realtime 3D graphics, offline 3D graphics, sound, etc.

The lifetime of a typical Renderer looks like this:

  1. The Renderer is created.

  2. The controlling application calls getUIComponent to ask the Renderer for a JComponent containing the Renderer's user interface.

  3. The controlling application calls setWorld to tell the Renderer the World it will be rendering. The Renderer may do some pre-processing at this point to prepare for later rendering. Interactive Renderers may choose to render the World in its initial state. Offline Renderers that need specialized configuration could pop up a configuration dialog.

  4. The controlling application may make repeated calls to the Renderer's render method. In between calls to render the World is usually taken through simulated steps of time.

  5. The controlling application calls the Renderer's finish method to indicate that the Renderer should shutdown. The Renderer should perform any necessary cleanup now.

In addition to the lifetime events listed above, the controlling application may call other Renderer methods at certain times.

  • Renderer's with a configuration dialog (that is, their hasSettingsDialog method returns true) may have their showSettings called at any time while render is not being called to indicate that the Renderer should pop up a configuration dialog.

  • The sync method may be called at any time while render is not being called to indicate that any asynchronous processing remaining from the last call to render should be completed. The sync method should block until all such processing has finished.

  • The #cancel()cancel method may be called while a call to render is in progress to indicate that the current rendering is being cancelled and should return immediately.

  • The controlling application may call a Renderer's getName and getDescription methods at any time to get information about the Renderer.
